query:
<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving powers/Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS/Subject>
<Question>
\[
3 \times 2+4-5
\]
Where do the brackets need to go to make the answer equal \( 13 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>Does not need brackets</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the order of operations, believes addition comes before multiplication </Misconception>
response:
<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving powers/Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS/Subject>
<Question>
\[
2 \times 3+10-2
\]
Where do the brackets need to go to make the answer equal \( 15 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>Does not need brackets</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the order of operations, believes addition comes before multiplication </Misconception>

query:

<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions/Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following, if possible: \( \frac{m^{2}+2 m-3}{m-3} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( m+1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that to factorise a quadratic expression, to find two numbers that add to give the coefficient of the x term, and multiply to give the non variable term
</Misconception>

query:
<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data/Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data/Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing the \( 5 \) plants with these heights:
\( 24 \mathrm{~cm}, 17 \mathrm{~cm}, 42 \mathrm{~cm}, 26 \mathrm{~cm}, 13 \mathrm{~cm} \)
Tom says if all the plants were cut in half, the range wouldn't change.
Katie says if all the plants grew by \( 3 \mathrm{~cm} \) each, the range wouldn't change.
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes if you changed all values by the same proportion the range would not change</Misconception>
response:
<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
A bookshelf has 5 books with the following widths:
15 cm, 20 cm, 18 cm, 12 cm, 22 cm
If all the books are replaced with new ones that are each 2 cm wider, what happens to the range of the book widths?
</Question>
<Answer>The range remains the same</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes if you changed all values by the same proportion the range would not change</Misconception>

query:
<Construct>Substitute positive integer values into formulae involving powers or roots/Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula/Subject>
<Question>
The equation \( f=3 r^{2}+3 \) is used to find values in the table below. What is the value covered by the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline\( r \) & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline\( f \) & \( 6 \) & \( 15 \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 24 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you can find missing values in a given table by treating the row as linear and adding on the difference between the first two values given.</Misconception>
response:
<Construct>Substitute positive integer values into formulae involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>

\hline\( r \) & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline\( A \) & \( 6 \) & \( 10 \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 14 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you can find missing values in a given table by treating the row as linear and adding on the difference between the first two values given.</Misconception>

query:
<Construct>Expand products of three binomials in the form (x + a)(x + b)(x + c)/Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Triple Brackets and more/Subject>
<Question>
John is expanding these three brackets:
\(
(x+5)(x-3)(x+6)
\)

He finds it helpful to split the first bracket and view the problem as follows:
\(
x(x-3)(x+6)+5(x-3)(x+6)
\)

He expands the brackets further. Before he simplifies, what are the terms than contain an \( \boldsymbol{x}^{2} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}+6 x^{2} \\ +3 x^{2} \\ +5 x^{2}\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores negative sign when expanding bracket</Misconception>
response:
<Question>
Sarah is expanding these three brackets:
\(
(x+2)(x-1)(x+4)
\)

She finds it helpful to split the first bracket and view the problem as follows:
\(
x(x-1)(x+4)+2(x-1)(x+4)
\)

She expands the brackets further. Before she simplifies, what are the terms that contain an \( \boldsymbol{x}^{2} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}+4 x^{2} \\ +2 x^{2} \\ +x^{2}\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores negative sign when expanding bracket</Misconception>

query:
<Construct>Compare relative frequencies in order to determine which prediction is likely to be more reliable/Construct>
<Subject>Experimental Probability and Relative Frequency/Subject>
<Question>
A vegetarian restaurant wants to know people's eating habits
\( 50 \) people in Town \( A \) are asked if they eat meat. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{ Town A } \\
\hline Do you eat meat? & Frequency \\
\hline Yes & \( 39 \) \\
\hline No & \( 11 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} \( 200 \) people in Town B are asked if they eat meat. \begin{tabular}{|cc|}
\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{ Town B } \\
\hline Do you eat meat? & Frequency \\
\hline Yes & \( 143 \) \\
\hline No & \( 57 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Which results are more reliable?
</Question>
<Answer>Town A</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that sample size affects reliability</Misconception>
response:
<Construct>Identify the effect of sample size on the reliability of a prediction</Construct>
<Subject>Data Analysis and Sampling/Subject>
<Question>

The heights of \( 30 \) people in City \( X \) are measured. The average height is \( 175 \) cm. The heights of \( 150 \) people in City \( Y \) are measured. The average height is \( 172 \) cm. Which result is more reliable?
</Question>
<Answer>City Y</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that sample size affects reliability</Misconception>

\)

\(
y=x^{2}-x-6 \geq 0 ?
\) ![The is a parabolic graph that crosses the x axis at the points (-2,0) and (3,0) and crosses the y axis at (0, -6).]()

<Misconception>Believes the solution of a quadratic inequality is always the interval between the roots</Misconception>

<Answer>\( \{x<-5\) or \(x>1\} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the solution of a quadratic inequality is always the interval between the roots</Misconception>

response:

\)

<Distractors>
\{x >-3\} \cup\{x <-2\}
\{-3 \leq x \leq -2\}
\{x <-3\} \cap\{x >-2\}
</Distractors>

= & \frac{x-1}{6} \times \frac{9}{x^{2}-1}

\)

<Misconception>Answers order of operations questions with brackets as if the brackets are not there</Misconception>

\(\frac{x^{2}+4x+4}{(x+2)(x+2)} \times \frac{x-2}{x+2}\)

\(\frac{(x+2)(x+2)}{x^{2}-4} \times \frac{x-2}{x+2}\)
</Distractors>

Tom says if you know the location of \( M \) only, then there is more than one possible location for \( \mathrm{P} \) and \( \mathrm{Q} \).

Katie says if you only know the locations of \( M \) and \( Q \), then there is more than one possible location for \( \mathrm{P} \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes there is more than one line which passes through a given pair of points</Misconception>

There are multiple possible values of x x = 4 x = -1 x = 7 B Believes there is more than one line which passes through a given pair of points

Tom</Answer>

query:
<Construct>Use the nth term rule of an ascending integer linear sequence to test whether a term belongs in the sequence or not/Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)/Subject>
<Question>
Eliza is trying to work out if \( 82 \) is a term in the sequence \( 3 n+1 \)

Below is her working out. What conclusion should Eliza draw?

 \( \begin{aligned} 3 n+1 & =82 \\ 3 n & =81 \\ n & =27\end{aligned} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 27 \) is in the sequence and is the \( 82^{\text {nd }} \) term</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up term in a sequence and position of a term</Misconception>
response:

\[ \begin{aligned} 2 n+11 & =63 \\ 2 n & =52 \\ n & =26\end{aligned} \]
</Question>
<Answer>26 is in the sequence and is the 63rd term</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up term in a sequence and position of a term</Misconception>

query:

Jo does: \( 15 \times 3+4 \)
Paul does: \( (15+2) \times 3-4 \)
Who is correct? ![The 3rd and 4th terms in a sequence of patterns. Each pattern is made from red squares. Pattern 3 is 11 squares: they are arranged as a rectangle, 3 squares high and 3 squares wide and then 2 more squares, 1 each side of the middle squares (vertically). Pattern 4 is 14 squares arranged as a rectangle, 3 squares high and 4 squares wide and then 2 more squares, 1 each side of the middle squares.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Jo</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes nth term rules for patterns must be given in standard an + b form</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>B</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes nth term rules for patterns must be given in standard an + b form</Misconception>

query:
<Construct>Solve problems that combine addition and subtraction/Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS/Subject>
<Question>
![Think of a number, then subtract \( 5 \), next divide by \( 8 \), next add 4, and finally multiply by \( 7 \).]() Jo says you can write this as:
\[
7\left(\frac{(n-5)}{8}+4\right)
\]
Paul says you can write this as:
\[
7((n-5) \div 8)+4
\]
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>
response:

\[
\frac{(n+2) \times 3 - 4}{2}
\]
Paul says you can write this as:
\[
(n+2) \times 3 - 4 \div 2
\]
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

query:
<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division/Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS/Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing the order of operations
Tom says: \( 3+2-1 \equiv 3-1+2 \)
Katie says: \( 3+2 \times 1 \equiv 2 \times 1+3 \)
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Performs addition ahead of multiplication</Misconception>
response:
<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the expression: \( 5+2 \times 4-1 \)
Who is correct?
A) Sarah says: \( 5+2 \times 4-1 \equiv (5+2) \times 4-1 \)
B) Alex says: \( 5+2 \times 4-1 \equiv 5+2-(4-1) \)
C) Jack says: \( 5+2 \times 4-1 \equiv 5+(2 \times 4)-1 \)
D) Emily says: \( 5+2 \times 4-1 \equiv 5+8-1 \)
</Question>
<Answer>C) Jack says: \( 5+2 \times 4-1 \equiv 5+(2 \times 4)-1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Performs addition ahead of multiplication</Misconception>

query:
<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division/Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS/Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing the order of operations
Tom says: \( 3+2-1 \equiv 3-1+2 \)
Katie says: \( 3+2 \times 1 \equiv 2 \times 1+3 \)
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>
response:
<Construct>Evaluate expressions using the correct order of operations/Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS/Subject>
<Question>
Solve the expression: \( 2 \times 3 + 11 - 4 \)
Which of the following is true?
A) \( 2 \times 3 + 11 - 4 \equiv 2 \times 3 - 4 + 11 \)
B) \( 2 \times 3 + 11 - 4 \equiv 2 \times (3 + 11) - 4 \)
C) \( 2 \times 3 + 11 - 4 \equiv 2 \times 3 + 11 - 4 \)
D) \( 2 \times 3 + 11 - 4 \equiv (2 - 4) \times 3 + 11 \)
</Question>
<Answer>C</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>
